episodes.title: Babylonian Toilet Paper | Ep014 | Letters From Listeners
episodes.description: In our final episode of the season we dive into a treasure trove of archived materials from the 1970s that expose the secrets of The Living Word Fellowship’s bizarre doomsday preparations. These guidelines were delivered on leaflets that we recently received from a former follower of John Robert Stevens’ cult. We share more revealing letters from listeners, including another former tape editor with tea from the tape room. We also hear from a couple of Kalona, Iowa locals who experienced the cultiness of the Shiloh compound first-hand.   Scott Barker and Charity Navalesi are former members, born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship. They are investigating this organization, founded by John Robert Stevens in 1951, that branded itself as a Christian church for over seventy years but turned out to be just another cult. Stevens demanded full submission of his followers until his death in 1983 and when his successors, Gary & Marilyn Hargrave took over, the beliefs and practices became even more extreme as they levied control over the congregants for the next three decades.   In 2018 a former member finally spoke up after Marilyn's death accusing her son of abuse. There are five active lawsuits. The organization is a shadow of what it once was, but some remain believers of John Robert Stevens' teachings and many maintain loyalty to Gary Hargrave. Gary has a new following on social media and an active "ministry".  ----- If you or someone you know has a mental illness, is struggling emotionally, or has concerns about their mental health, there are ways to get help. Use these resources to find help for you, a friend, or a family member:  ⁠⁠⁠https://988lifeline.org/⁠⁠⁠ ⁠⁠⁠https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/find-help⁠⁠⁠ Podcast Links:  Apple: https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/oops-im-in-a-cult/id1703501829  Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/show/2YlZeTiuons5y4J3RZYXSv    Contact Oops! eMail - contactwalkdoc@gmail.com  Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/thecultdoc  TikTok - https://www.tiktok.com/@thewalkdoc  More - https://linktr.ee/thewalkdoc  ---   Support this podcast: https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/oopsiminacult/support

episodes.title: I Was Born The Day I Left | Ep013 | Interview with Johanna Wozniak
episodes.description: Johanna Wozniak was born and raised in the Los Angeles chapter of The Living Word Fellowship and attended the church school from pre-school until her senior year. She spent most nights of her childhood in the church’s recording studio which was run by accused serial abuser and leader Rick Holbrook. She talks about how her troubled home life caused her to seek out family in the form of the church despite its toxicity by immersing herself in the never-ending work. She discusses her abrupt and dramatic exit from the Fellowship and how she was immediately shunned for making one big decision without the church’s permission. She shares with us how she had to rebuild her life on her own just a week after her eighteenth birthday. Johanna says, “I was born the day I left.” Scott Barker and Charity Navalesi are former members, born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship. They are investigating this organization, founded by John Robert Stevens in 1951, that branded itself as a Christian church for over seventy years but turned out to be just another cult. Stevens demanded full submission of his followers until his death in 1983 and when his successors, Gary & Marilyn Hargrave took over, the beliefs and practices became even more extreme as they levied control over the congregants for the next three decades.   In 2018 a former member finally spoke up after Marilyn's death accusing her son of abuse. There are five active lawsuits. The organization is a shadow of what it once was, but some remain believers of John Robert Stevens' teachings and many maintain loyalty to Gary Hargrave. Gary has a new following on social media and an active "ministry".  If you or someone you know has a mental illness, is struggling emotionally, or has concerns about their mental health, there are ways to get help. episodes.title: Is Religion Inherently Abusive? | Ep012 | Interview with Larry Bobo
episodes.description: Larry Bobo joined The Living Word Fellowship in Des Moines, Iowa in 1969. From there he watched as leadership was expelled for not fully submitting to John Robert Stevens’ teachings. As a teenager he experienced sexual abuse at the hands of a leader and a another member of the church. In later years he became a leader himself and was relocated to the Colorado church where he called out inconsistencies in the Living Word doctrine to Marilyn and Gary Hargrave and the head leadership of the Fellowship in a detailed letter. Afterwords he was immediately silenced, literally being told he was not allowed to speak in the church. Eventually he left the Fellowship and discovered his own path back into Christianity. We talk with Larry about personal relationships with God, abuse in Christian churches and what being a Christian means to him.  Larry's letter to TLW leaders https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/02uif2gyiffd5hjmpk71i/CS-Shepherds1.pdf?rlkey=02pakfvazvyhs3pdidgmspepr&dl=0  Scott Barker  and Charity Navalesi are former members, born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship. They are investigating this organization, founded by John Robert Stevens in 1951, that branded itself as a Christian church for over seventy years but turned out to be just another cult. Stevens demanded full submission of his followers until his death in 1983 and when his successors, Gary & Marilyn Hargrave took over, the beliefs and practices became even more extreme as they levied control over the congregants for the next three decades.   In 2018 a former member finally spoke up after Marilyn's death accusing her son of abuse. There are five active lawsuits. The organization is a shadow of what it once was, but some remain believers of John Robert Stevens' teachings and many maintain loyalty to Gary Hargrave. Gary has a new following on social media and an active "ministry". episodes.title: Shamed, Blamed, & Silenced | Oops! I'm In a Cult EP010 | Interview with Lauren Beckman
episodes.description: Lauren Beckman was born and raised in The LIving Word Fellowship, her early life spent in San Diego where she was separated from her mother as a teenager and sent to be a live-in servant for her shepherd where she was physically, emotionally and mentally abused. In early adulthood, she moved to the Church of The Living Word in Los Angeles, where the abuse only escalated. Not only was Lauren regularly abused by Rick Holbrook, but she shares with us a traumatic sexual assault perpetrated by a member of the Fellowship, which was covered up by church leadership, including Marilyn and Gary Hargrave. Through all of the abuses she endured, Lauren was instructed not to tell her mother, report abuses to authorities, or seek professional help. She tells us about the lasting effects these experiences have on her and how she continues to work toward healing. ______________________________________  Scott and Charity are former members, born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship. They are investigating this organization, founded by John Robert Stevens in 1951, that branded itself as a Christian church for over seventy years but turned out to be just another cult. Stevens demanded full submission of his followers until his death in 1983 and when his successors, Gary & Marilyn Hargrave took over, the beliefs and practices became even more extreme as they levied control over the congregants for the next three decades.  In 2018 a former member finally spoke up after Marilyn's death accusing her son of abuse. episodes.title: Deprogramming and Detoxing | Ep009
episodes.description: AKA: A nuclear wasteland of shit! In this episode of Oops, Scott and Charity talk about the process of recognizing that they no longer wished to be a part of The Living Word Fellowship. They discuss cult expert Rick Ross's signs you might be in a cult or high control group. They share their experiences of recognizing that they were a part of an unhealthy community, the process they went through to acknowledge that The Living Word Fellowship was in fact a cult, and the realization that this was just the beginning of their journey into healing from the trauma of being raised in such a group. They talk about how there is always further work to be done and what that looks like for them.  Scott and Charity are former members, born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship. They are investigating this organization, founded by John Robert Stevens in 1951, that branded itself as a Christian church for over seventy years but turned out to be just another cult. episodes.title: Power and Privilege | EP007 | Interview with Adam Beatty
episodes.description: Adam Beatty was a member of the original Southgate, CA church, Grace Chapel, as well as the Shiloh, IA faction of The Living Word Fellowship. Adam talks with us about his family's history in The Walk, starting in the John Robert Stevens days, his experience with power dynamics and racism within the Fellowship, and learning to maintain relationships with friends and family members who still believe the cult's teachings, while making room for his own healing and the healing of others. episodes.title: To Be a Charlatan | EP006 | John Robert Stevens and The Walk
episodes.description: What is the truth about John Robert Stevens? Throughout the history of The Living Word Fellowship cult rumors circulated about John's purported infidelities and indiscretions, but these rumors were always excused away by the belief that his "apostleship" outweighed the importance of any questionable behavior. His claims of time travel and having the power to cause the deaths of people he deemed nephilim such as John Lennon and the John F. Kennedy were among the many unbelievable things that his followers bought into. These excuses were perpetuated by his successor, Gary Hargrave. In this episode we delve into these topics and reveal our findings on one of the most recent and biggest allegations against JRS: that he plagiarized his manifesto "To Be A Christian", which was the legacy of his ministry.  If you or someone you know has a mental illness, is struggling emotionally, or has concerns about their mental health, there are ways to get help. episodes.title: An Outside Perspective | EP005 | Interview With Beau Brown
episodes.description: On this episode we sit down with Beau Brown who gives us his perspective on The Living Word Cult as an outsider looking in. Beau never attended the church itself, but was a student at the Living Word based school, Centers of Learning, in North Hills, California, which was originally attended only by members of TLWF and later opened up to the public. His unique observations as a non-member give us a window into how bizarre the church and its practices came across to the outside world. episodes.title: Bad Boy Boot Camp | EP 004 | Interview with Titus Walker
episodes.description: In this episode we talk with Titus Walker, who was born into The Living Word Fellowship and remained a devoted member until his early twenties when he was unceremoniously kicked out of the church by its top leadership, Marilyn and Gary Hargrave. Titus reveals how this excommunication propelled him down a dark path, having lost almost everything and everyone he had ever known. He discusses how this event, preceded by years of mental and emotional abuse the church perpetrated on him, has deeply affected his life. episodes.title: A Cult Exposed | Ep003
episodes.description: In this episode we delve into the 2018 letters that forever changed the course of The Living Word Fellowship, bringing the truth of the rampant abuse in the organization to light. We discuss the details of the letters Shalom Abrahamson published on Facebook, how they reflected the toxic leadership structure and controlling culture of the Fellowship, and why her letters were instrumental in opening the eyes of members both past and current. episodes.title: Leni and Sam Davis | Ep002 | An Interview
episodes.description: On today's episode, we talk with Leni Davis and her son Sam, former members of the Oahu, Hawaii chapter of The Living Word Fellowship, known as Grace Chapel of Honolulu. Leni and Sam discuss why Leni joined the fellowship in the early 1970's, her initial interactions with John Robert Stevens and how, in the years that followed, the toxicity of the organization affected her as an individual as well as her relationship with her child. Sam shares his experience being born and raised in the fellowship during the years after John Robert Stevens' passing, under the leadership of Gary & Marilyn Hargrave, and how its abusive culture impacted him as a child and as a gay man being brought up in a homophobic organization.  If you or someone you know has a mental illness, is struggling emotionally, or has concerns about their mental health, there are ways to get help. episodes.title: What is The Living Word | Ep001
episodes.description: What do you do when you realize that the church you grew up in was actually a cult? You make a podcast to talk all about it! Born and raised in The Living Word Fellowship, hosts Scott Barker and Charity Navalesi discuss their experiences growing up in this modern day cult, conducting in-depth interviews with other former members and exploring the hidden truths of an organization that masqueraded as a non-denominational Christian church for over 70 years, at its peak growing to 100 chapters in 10 countries. In 2018, a former member came forward on social media with allegations of mental, emotional and sexual abuse within the church, spawning a movement of truth-telling that caused the almost immediate demise of the organization, its entire leadership resigning as more and more accusations of misconduct were revealed. In this podcast we'll discuss the history of the organization, its ultimate collapse, and the effects of its abusive culture and toxic leadership on former members. Adding a touch of humor, because if you can't laugh about it, it just sucks too intensely, Scott and Charity unpack their and others' experiences, how they're recovering from religious abuse and navigating life today, and the moment they realized, "Oops! I'm in a cult!". Hey, it happens.   If you or someone you know has a mental illness, is struggling emotionally, or has concerns about their mental health, there are ways to get help. Use these resources to find help for you, a friend, or a family member:  https://988lifeline.org/ https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/find-help  eMail - contactwalkdoc@gmail.com Instagram - www.instagram.com/thecultdoc TikTok - www.tiktok.com/@thewalkdoc YouTube - www.youtube.com/@thewalkdoc More - linktr.ee/thewalkdoc

episodes.title: Sandy Navalesi feat Charity | A Living Word Cult Conversation
episodes.description:
Former Living Word Cult member surrendered her daughter to the cult. Through brainwashing, the Living Word's leader John Robert Stevens convinced Sandy to "break bonds" with her new born baby, Charity. In this conversation, Charity and Sandy discuss how this affected their relationship and in what ways it may have left life long scars. 

--------

In 2018 a former member of The Living Word Fellowship exposed sexual abuse by one of the TLW leaders, Rick Holbrook. She went on to show that the abuse was systematically covered up by the church's shepherding couple, Gary Hargrave and Marilyn Hargrave. In the middle of the #MeToo movement hundreds of former members took to Facebook to share their stories of abuse and manipulation condoned by the leaders in TLW churches across the country from North Hills, CA to Kalona, Iowa, from Haiku, Hawaii to Niterói, Brazil. Through the decades, former Living Word Fellowship members reveled financial fraud, sexual abuse, physical abuse, mental manipulation, brainwashing, forced labor, separating families, arranged marriages, underaged drinking, and more.  It's clear from the multigenerational cult members and their testimony that all of this stemmed from the very founding of the cult in the 1950s with their beloved Apostle, John Robert Stevens.

episodes.title: Sarah Olaguez | A Living Word Cult Conversion
episodes.description:
Sarah was brought into the church via the "Kingdom School" and eventually joined the church giving all her free time to the desires of the leaders. In this conversation she takes us through her life as she was coerced, manipulated and discarded by the leaders using the 'designed relationship" and shepherding system. 

**Note: At 01:15:00 the paddle didn't actually say "Board of Education" that was a different more creative principal. But the paddle was in her office and had air holes for speed.

-----

In 2018 a former member of The Living Word Fellowship exposed sexual abuse by one of the TLW leaders, Rick Holbrook. She went on to show that the abuse was systematically covered up by the church's shepherding couple, Gary Hargrave and Marilyn Hargrave. In the middle of the #MeToo movement hundreds of former members took to Facebook to share their stories of abuse and manipulation condoned by the leaders in TLW churches across the country from North Hills, CA to Kalona, Iowa, from Haiku, Hawaii to Niterói, Brazil. Through the decades, former Living Word Fellowship members reveled financial fraud, sexual abuse, physical abuse, mental manipulation, brainwashing, forced labor, separating families, arranged marriages, underaged drinking, and more.  It's clear from the multigenerational cult members and their testimony that all of this stemmed from the very founding of the cult in the 1950s with their beloved Apostle, John Robert Stevens.

episodes.title: Macie and Frank | A Living Word Conversion - Part 2
episodes.description:
Macie continues her story from The Living Word Cult by bring in her husband Frank Chadwick. They met and fell in love as teenagers during the era of John Robert Stevens and The Walk. When they submitted their relationship Macie says that's when she was kicked out of the church and her home. 

the process of submitting to the shepherds everything in your life including who you wanted to date was a common occurrence in the living word cult. Many times members were given an ultimatum. The Living Word Cult's take on Arranged Marriages.



-----


In 2018 a former member of The Living Word Fellowship exposed sexual abuse by one of the TLW leaders, Rick Holbrook. She went on to show that the abuse was systematically covered up by the church's shepherding couple, Gary Hargrave and Marilyn Hargrave. In the middle of the #MeToo movement hundreds of former members took to Facebook to share their stories of abuse and manipulation condoned by the leaders in TLW churches across the country from North Hills, CA to Kalona, Iowa, from Haiku, Hawaii to Niterói, Brazil. Through the decades, former Living Word Fellowship members reveled financial fraud, sexual abuse, physical abuse, mental manipulation, brainwashing, forced labor, separating families, arranged marriages, underaged drinking, and more.  It's clear from the multigenerational cult members and their testimony that all of this stemmed from the very founding of the cult in the 1950s with their beloved Apostle, John Robert Stevens.

episodes.title: Jackson Veigel | A Living Word Cult Conversation
episodes.description:
Rick Holbrook's audio department in The Living Word Cult was a training ground for kids to learn the ways of the Word of John Robert Stevens and Gary Hargrave. The purpose was to record and preserve the "word" for future generations of Christians. Jackson and Scott were trained from a young age to work under Rick at the TLW music studio at the "building" and in the audio booths of the North Hills Church of the Living Word and Grace Chapel of South Gate churches. Jack explains that the toxic culture of the Living Word was unavoidable and how he was 100% devoted to the work he was doing whether it was in California or at the Shiloh compound in Kalona, Iowa. Both Scott and Jack explore how working for Rick in their formative years still affects them today.

----

episodes.title: Charity Navalesi | A Living Word Cult Conversation
episodes.description:
Before Shalom released the letters that dismantled the Living Word Cult, she first reached out to her close friend Charity Navalesi for support. In Episode 2 of the documentary we can see that story play out as it did in 2018.Today, Charity describes this action as the thing "I'm most proud of in my whole life." 
With Charity's support (among others) Shalom was able to strike a blow at the heart of the Living Word Cult and speak a truth that freed so many others from the control of the leadership. 
In this video former member and documentary filmmaker Scott Barker sits down with Charity to talk about this incredibly important time and all of her experiences growing up in this fundamentalist new age cult. 

---

episodes.title: How One Woman Exposed a Cult | The Living Word Cult Series | Ep 2
episodes.description:
In 2018 The Living Word Fellowship was hit with a sexual abuse scandal they didn't see coming. A former member released letters showing that she had been sexually harassed and abused by the TLW leadership for years. Further, she showed that the church used their system of control to "shame, blame and silence" her for almost 20 years. Only when Shalom Abrahamson spoke out was the leadership forced to respond. 
What followed was an unprecedented exodus of members from the church, many of whom reached out on social media to show their support to Shalom and additionally share their own stories of abuse from the church leaders. 
This episode dives into the most telling moments from Shalom's letters, how and why she decided to post them, and the system of control the leaders of the church used to protect the abusers and silence their victims.

episodes.title: They Told Us “Don't Say Church” | The Living Word Cult
episodes.description:
A little behind the scenes look at how we hid the church from the residents of North Hollywood and even the 11 O'clock news. 

Why did Rick and the church want to keep the Tuck publicly separate from the church? Was it because we didn't celebrate Christmas? But then why would we do it at all if we didn't believe in celebrating Christmas? The Truck was a spectacular production that came at great cost and at no point did we share with the neighbors why we put this huge production on or that we were all members of The Living Word Church of North Hollywood and North Hills. 

However as members we were pressured into not only showing up for the 8 hour night of singing and dancing, but also to donate, work, and train for the big Holiday Parade every year for almost 35 years.

episodes.title: Cult run “Christmas Caroling Truck” | The Living Word Cult Series | Ep 1
episodes.description:
It’a a clear quiet Christmas Eve. You stand from your window and you spy the most wonderful thing! 

For 35 years the residents of North Hollywood eagerly made camp on their front lawns awaiting the Magical Christmas Caroling Truck musical parade!  To some, this event, on the darkest night of the year, is “more important than Christmas Day”.  Families pour out of their home and sing along as The Truck passed by. Drinks in hand they follow the Christmas truck and its trail of dancing “candy cane girls” up and down the streets of the San Fernando Valley. After three decades, many residents can’t imagine or remember a single Christmas without the presence of The Magical Christmas Caroling Truck. 

This Holiday Parade recruited 150 volunteers including the dancers, the singers, the drivers, security, and of course Santa himself. Its sound system rivaled the Macy’s Day parade floats and definitely beat out even the most outlandish of the neighbor’s light displays. Bright and loud, the truck boasted that its creators and volunteers come from the Hollywood studios right down the street - Warner Brothers, Universal, and Disney.  

However the truth, that was not advertised on the 11 o’clock news, was that the volunteers and sponsors of the Holiday Christmas event were all from The Church of The Living Word in North Hills California. In the weeks leading up to the event they trained in a recording studio owned by The Living Word Church in an industrial section of North Hollywood just under the Burbank Airport flight path. The money that funded the Magical Christmas Truck came from donations to The Living Word Fellowship. And the creator and inventor of the Toluca Lake Holiday Truck was one of the head pastors of the The Living Word. 

The separating line that was intentionally drawn between the truck and the church would keep many of the neighbors in the North Hollywood, Teluca Lake, Burbank neighborhoods from knowing the absolute chaos that was raining down on the this Pastor and creator of The Magical Christmas Caroling Truck. One October night in the hight of the #metoo era, a former member of the TLW church posted a damning letter that tarnished the reputation of Rick Holbrook (the creator of the truck) and the heads of the Living Word Church, Gary and Marilyn Hargrave. After reading the letters, members of the church began to post stories of their own further dragging these three Christian leaders down into the dirt. By the time Christmas came around members of the Living Word could not care less about the Magical Christmas Caroling Truck. 

This is only the beginning of the story.

CREDITS:
EP 1 - Magical Christmas Caroling Cult

episodes.title: Christmas in Los Angeles | The Living Word Cult
episodes.description:
On Christmas Eve, for 35 years, the residents of North Hollywood, CA eagerly awaited the arrival of the Magical Christmas Caroling Truck. To some, this tradition was more important than Christmas Day itself. However, the residents couldn’t know that behind the smiling faces of the carolers and pretty costumed dancers there was a sinister secret. 

The Living Word church The Living word Fellowship, The Living Word cult, has controlled every detail of its members lives for over 70 years. Now the former members are now fighting back.
